#Text=3 .
#Text=Transmission Schemes
#Text=In this section , a conventional non-jamming scheme and two source cooperative jamming schemes are presented for the considered buffer-aided relay IoT networks .
#Text=3.1 .
#Text=NJ Scheme
#Text=The total transmission is divided into two hops .
#Text=In the first hop , the source sensor S sends the signal to the relay sensor while intercepted by K eavesdroppers .

#Text=Hence , the received SNR at and can be , respectively , expressed as ( 4 ) ( 5 ) where denotes the transmit power of the source sensor , which obeys the uniform power allocation for ease of analysis . and represent the channel gains of link and , is the variance of the additive white Gaussian noise ( AWGN ) .

#Text=Similar to the first hop , the received SNR at D and can be , respectively , given by ( 6 ) ( 7 ) where is the transmit power of the selected relay sensor , and and denote the channel gains of link and , respectively .
#Text=Due to the presence of multiple eavesdroppers , we take both NCE and CE scenarios into account .
#Text=In the NCE scenario , the eavesdroppers decode information individually without interactions .
#Text=Hence , the received signal-to-noise ratio ( SNR ) at the eavesdroppers of the first and second hops can be , respectively , given by ( 8 ) ( 9 )
#Text=In the CE scenario , all eavesdroppers can exchange the information with each other and adopt the maximal ratio combining ( MRC ) for enhancing the intercept ability .

#Text=Thus , the instantaneous SNR of the eavesdroppers ’ channels for the first and second hops are expressed as ( 10 ) ( 11 ) where denotes the channel vector between the source sensor and the eavesdroppers .
#Text=Similarly , represents the channel vector between the selected relay sensor and the eavesdroppers .
#Text=The NJ scheme is a benchmark invoked for the purpose of comparison , which can also be applicable for the practical application scenario due to it lower complexity .
#Text=3.2 .
#Text=SCJ Scheme

#Text=In this case , when the second hop is selected , the source sensor can send jamming signals to the eavesdroppers with the transmit power , which degrades the quality of eavesdroppers ’ channels effectively without interfering other nodes .
#Text=Furthermore , due to the total power constraint , we have , where denotes the transmit power of the source sensor when transmitting useful information .
#Text=Similar to the NJ scheme , the power allocation follows the uniform allocation rule , i. e. , , .
#Text=The first hop of the SCJ scheme is the same as the NJ scheme , hence we have and .
#Text=In the second hop , the received signal-to-interference-plus-noise-ratio ( SINR ) at is given by ( 12 ) where denotes the link of when S acts as a jamming node .
#Text=Thus , for the NCE scenario , the received SNR and SINR at the eavesdroppers of the first and second hops can be written as ( 13 ) ( 14 )

#Text=For the CE mode , the received SNR and SINR of the eavesdroppers ’ channel for the first and second hops are given by ( 15 ) ( 16 ) where represents the channel vector between the source sensor and the eavesdroppers when the source acts as a jamming node .
#Text=3.3 .
#Text=SCJ-OPA Scheme
#Text=To further enhance the physical layer security for the SCJ scheme , the optimal power allocation operation is employed at the source sensor node under the SCJ-OPA scheme .
#Text=Similar to the section above , we still assume that .
#Text=Then , we have .
#Text=Given and where denotes the power allocation factor .
#Text=We aim to find the optimal power allocation factor to minimize the secrecy outage probability of the considered system .
#Text=Therefore , the optimization problem can be written as ( 17 ) where represents the overall secrecy outage probability of the system .
#Text=We derive the expression of the secrecy outage probability and solve the optimization in the following section .

#Text=Moreover , making an appropriate substitution of the parameters , i. e. , and , the received SNR or SINR at the corresponding node under the SCJ-OPA scheme can be obtained easily , hence is omitted .
#Text=Now , according to the authors of , the achievable secrecy rate of the first and second hops can be , respectively , expressed as ( 18 ) ( 19 ) where , , , .
